data.text: @ncdave4life I don't know what this link is supposed to represent but the vax doesn't reduce the spread. If you think it does you're seriously confused.

@VictorJennpaul @B_Bolshevik100 Both high-risk populations (elderly, obese, patients w/ cancer, kidney disease, pulmonary disease, liver disease, cardiovascular & cerebrovascular disease, etc.) and low-risk populations (young & healthy) benefit from vaccination. (High-risk benefit most.)
https://t.co/el8ObddwKY

@B_Bolshevik100 @ncdave4life You're asking for data transparency. You won't get it.

Australia spent far too much on too many vaccines (instead of supporting Australian candidates), and they're using that sunk cost to keep the business owners happy to win the election.
@B_Bolshevik100 To cover this up, they want everyone sick.

@ncdave4life @B_Bolshevik100 The fact still remains that most fatalities were in the elderly and obese with comorbidities. The one size fits all model suited big pharma but has been a disaster for the majority of the population, the effects of which are still to be calculated. https://t.co/zwEmPSjo7i
@B_Bolshevik100 Here is the data compared to the average population in each vax rate cohort. My data is 2 weeks older than yours, but it shows the point you are making. https://t.co/A9xYCKj2Zf

@B_Bolshevik100 Untrue. I don't know what those first 3 graphs are supposed to represent, and the 4th image/table is unreadable. But if you think the unvaccinated have lower infection rates, or lower rates of serious illness or death, in the US or UK, you are confused.

https://t.co/zUiGhA7ceD

@ncdave4life No. How is this an indication of infection reduction?

The UK NHS shows that the unvaccinated have lower infection rates. https://t.co/2i2WuHh48z

@ncdave4life I'm talking about NSW. 

The vax obviously doesn't reduce the spread as we had more cases after 95% vax rates than during the entire 2 years that preceded it.
